Riptide Gas Plant
Risk Management Plan (RMP) Documentation
February 2019
Inventory of Materials
An inventory of materials and regulated substances at the Riptide Gas Plant was developed from
the volumes of vessels and piping from the process and instrument diagrams (P&IDs), process
flow diagrams, and heat and material balance. Lengths of lines and volumes of certain vessels
were assumed based on good engineering practices. A table of inventory is shown in Appendix
1. Only administrative controls can be credited when limiting volumes in vessels per the General
Guidance on Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accident Prevention (40 CFR Part 68)
chapter 4.2. In order to establish the safest possible environment for EnLink's employees and the
public, there are no regulated toxic substances above threshold quantities present at the Riptide
Gas Plant.
Applicability of Program Levels
Location of facility
EnLink Midstream Partners operates the Riptide Gas Plant in Martin County, Texas. The facility
is located approximately 4.51 miles southwest of Lenorah, Texas. Its coordinates are
32.24305°N, -101.90355°W. The address for the facility is 3014 FM 829 Lenorah, TX 79749.
The facility is surrounded by undeveloped land. Tarzan is approximately 6.03 miles northwest of
the facility and Stanton is approximately 10.34 miles southeast of the facility. A recent aerial
photograph, site location map, USGS topographic map and plot plan of the area around the
Riptide Gas Plant are presented in Appendix 2.
Definition of Program Levels
Program 1: Processes which would not affect the public in the case of a worst-case release (in the
language of Part 68, processes "with no public receptors within the distance to an endpoint from
a worst-case release") and with no accidents with specific offsite consequences within the past
five years are eligible for Program 1, which imposes limited hazard assessment requirements and
minimal prevention and emergency response req

uirements.
Program 2: Processes not eligible for Program 1 or subject to Program 3 are placed in Program 2,
which imposes streamlined prevention program requirements, as well as additional hazard
assessment, management, and emergency response requirements.
Program 3: Processes not eligible for Program 1 and either subject to OSHA's PSM standard
under federal or state OSHA programs or classified in one of ten specified North American
Industrial Classification System (NAICS) codes are placed in Program 3, which imposes
OSHA's PSM standard as the prevention program as well as additional hazard assessment,
management, and emergency response requirements.
Riptide Gas Plant, RMP Page 3
Determination of Program Level
The Riptide Gas Plant is a "Program 1" process. The facility is eligible for "Program 1" as it
does not have a public receptor within the distance to the endpoint of 1 psi overpressure from a
vapor cloud explosion for each regulated substance.
The EPA program "RMP*COMP" ver. 2.01 was used to determine the endpoint for the "worstcase"
scenario for each regulated substance. The following worst-case scenarios were analyzed:
➢ Flammable Mixture - Slug Catcher, SC-100 failure - 784,000 lbs.
➢ Propane - Refrigerant Accumulator, V-463 failure - 18,600 lbs.
EPA's program yielded the following endpoint for each regulated substance:
➢ Flammable Mixture - 0.7 miles
➢ Propane - 0.2 miles
The closest public receptor is approximately 3,827 ft. (0.72 miles) from the vessels in the
analysis.
According to EnLink personnel, the Riptide Gas Plant has had no accidents in the last five years;
therefore the accident history has no bearing on the program determination.
Offsite Consequence Analysis
Worst-case Case Scenarios
The EPA program "RMP*COMP" ver. 2.01 was used to determine the vapor cloud explosion
endpoints to 1 psi overpressure for the "worst-case" scenario. The analysis determined that each
regulated substance held

above its threshold quantity did not have any public receptors within its
endpoint. EnLink Midstream Partners personnel agreed and confirmed this determination. A
worst-case scenario considers the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a
vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest affected distance. Since the Riptide Gas
Plant is considered a Program 1 facility, a worst-case scenario for each regulated substance, i.e.
Flammable Mixture and Propane must be considered. The specifics of each worst-case scenario
can be seen in Appendix 4.
Since this facility was determined to be a Program 1 process, no alternative scenarios were
considered.
The selected worst-case scenario for the Riptide Gas Plant is a release from the Slug Catcher,
SC-100 releasing approximately 784,000 lbs. of a Flammable Mixture. The endpoint to 1 psi of
overpressure for this scenario is 0.7 miles and is the greatest endpoint of all worst-case scenarios
considered for each regulated substance at the facility. Therefore, this scenario was the one
selected as the worst-case scenario for the process. It should be noted that the closest public
receptor is approximately 3,827 ft. (0.72 miles) from the vessels in the analysis.
Riptide Gas Plant, RMP Page 4
Alternative Scenarios
Since this facility was determined to be a Program 1 process, no alternative scenarios were
considered.
RMP Program Development
The following was developed to satisfy the management documentation as required by the RMP
rule and applies to each regulated substance in the Riptide Gas Plant. A copy of the RMP filed
with the EPA containing the RMP required information is available in Appendix 5.
Executive Summary - Riptide Gas Plant
EnLink Midstream Partners, owner and operator of the Riptide Gas Plant, has a long-standing
commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources
invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel an

d considering safety in the design,
installation, operation, and maintenance of the processes. EnLink's policy is to implement
reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a
release does occur, facility trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.
Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
Natural gas is gathered from wells in the surrounding fields and sent to the Riptide Gas Plant for
processing prior to being sold for domestic consumption. This gas contains impurities in the
form of carbon dioxide (CO2), nitrogen (N2) and water. These impurities must be brought into
specification before residue companies will purchase this gas. The Riptide Gas Plant inlet gas
contains enough natural gas liquids that extraction is desirable.
The Riptide Gas Plant is a non-fractionating NGL extraction plant that is designed to process
natural gas. The facility is designed for 100 MMSCFD. The plant consists of the following: inlet
gas separation and filtration, condensate stabilization, inlet compression, amine treatment unit,
dehydration, cryogenic processing unit, refrigeration system, residue compression, flare system,
and all associated utilities and ancillary systems. Condensate recovered from inlet gas is stored in
seven 750-barrel atmospheric tanks located within secondary containment areas and loaded into
tanker trucks for shipment. NGL from the cryogenic units and natural gas from residue
compression are sent offsite via pipeline without intermediate storage. The Ripley Compressor
Station is currently being built and will be installed within the facility boundary of the Riptide
Gas Plant. The station will be receiving approximately 20 MMSCFD of natural gas from Pioneer
Natural Resources. The station consists of inlet gas separation, filtration, and compression.
Captured liquids are sent to two 400-barrel Slop Tanks and to one 210-barrel Water Tank and
loaded into tanke

r trucks when needed. A vapor recovery unit is used to capture hydrocarbon
vapors off of the atmospheric tanks. Natural gas following compression is sent to the Riptide Gas
Plant for further processing.
Riptide Gas Plant, RMP Page 5
The processes at the facility are interconnected by piping and fit the EPA's definition of a
stationary source in 40 CFR part 68. The facility contains two sources of a regulated substance
held over its respective threshold quantity; Flammable Mixture and Propane.
Chemical - Specific Prevention Steps
The processes at the Riptide Gas Plant have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued
safe operation. The following is a description of existing safety features applicable to the
prevention of accidental releases of the regulated substance in the facility.
Specialized Safety Features
The Riptide Gas Plant has safety features on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2)
quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release. The following
types of safety features are used in the covered process:
Release Detection
1. Tanks are gauged
2. Tanks/vessels are equipped with level and pressure sensors
3. High/Low alarms and shutdowns
4. Facility is staffed 24-hours a day, 7-days a week
Release Containment/Control
1. Berms around tanks
2. Process relief valves venting vapors to the atmosphere or flare to prevent vessels from
rupturing
3. Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual and automated)
4. Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high temperature)
5. Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process
control system)
Release Mitigation
1. Trained emergency response personnel
2. Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing)
3. SPCC Plan
4. Fire extinguishers
Riptide Gas Plant, RMP Page 6
Emergency Response Program Information
The Riptide Gas Plant maintains a written emergency

response program, which is in place to
protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures
for responding to the release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or
explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects
of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures,
evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local
emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post incident cleanup and
decontamination requirements. In addition, the facility has procedures that address maintenance,
inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the
use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as
necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. The emergency response
program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes. The
emergency response program changes are administered through the Management of Change
(MOC) process, which includes informing and/or training affected personnel in the changes.
Periodic drills or tabletop exercises are conducted to test the response plan.
The overall emergency response program for the Riptide Gas Plant is coordinated with the
Martin County LEPC. Gary Walton is the contact for the LEPC and can be reached at (432) 607-
3557. The Riptide Gas Plant has around-the-clock communications capability. EnLink
Midstream Partners operators are automatically called in the event of a process upset. The
operator will then call the appropriate emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department).
This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating
quick response to an incident. EnLink Midstream Partners conducts periodic emergency drills
that involve emergency r

esponse organizations and the Riptide Gas Plant provides annual
refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in
the facility.
Five - Year Accident History
According to EnLink personnel, the Riptide Gas Plant has had no accidents in the last five years;
therefore the accident history has no bearing on the program determination.
Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The Riptide Gas Plant resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in modifications to
the process.
Record Keeping
The owner or operator of the Riptide Gas Plant should maintain this documentation supporting
the implementation of the RMP for five years (40 CFR part 68.200).
